question.text: An ideal gas is expanded from  <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfenced></math>  to  <math><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>)</mo></math>  under different conditions. The incorrect statement among the following is?

options.text: The word done by the gas is less when it is expanded reversibly from  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math>  to  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  under adiabatic conditions as compared to that when expanded reversibly from  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math>  to  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  under isothermal conditions

The change in internal energy of the gas is (i) zero, if it is expanded reversibly with  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>=</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>  and (ii) positive, if it is expanded reversibly under adiabatic conditions with  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>≠</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">T</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></math>
If the expansion is carried out freely, it is simultaneously both isothermal as well as adiabatic

The work done on the gas is maximum when it is compressed irreversibly from  <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfenced></math>  to  <math><mfenced separators="|"><mrow><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">V</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mfenced></math>  against constant pressure  <math><msub><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">p</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow></msub></math>

solution.text:
Area under curve in reversible isothermal is more. So, more work will be done by gas.

T1=T2

ΔU=nCVΔT=0

In reversible adiabatic expansion, T2<T1

So ΔT=-ve , ΔU=-ve

In free expansion, Pext=0

So W=0

If carried out isothermally ΔU=0

q=0 (adiabatic); from I law

If carried out adiabatically q=0

ΔU=0 (isothermal); From I law



During irreversible compression, maximum work is done on the gas (corresponding to shaded area).
